message.content:
A merism is a figure of speech in which a part or aspect of something is used to represent the whole thing. It's similar to synecdoche, but instead of using a part to represent a whole, a merism uses multiple parts to represent the whole.

For example, if I say "I ran all day," it's a synecdoche because I am using the part (all day) to represent the whole (24 hours). A merism would be if I said something like "I ran my legs off" or "my feet are killing me." In this case, I am using multiple parts of my body (legs and feet) to represent the whole act of running.

So, a merism is a figure of speech that uses multiple parts of something to represent the whole thing.
